docs.lead_paragraph: 1. The Cartoon and the Reality Bruce Tinsley's comic strip, ''Mallard Fillmore,'' is, he says, ''for the average person out there: the forgotten American taxpayer who's sick of the liberal media.'' In June, that forgotten taxpayer made an appearance in the strip, attacking his TV set with a baseball bat and yelling: ''I can't afford to send my kids to college, or even take 'em out of their substandard public school, because the federal, state and local governments take more than 50 percent of my income in taxes. And then the guy on the news asks with a straight face whether or not we can 'afford' tax cuts.''
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman article warns of dire implications for Americans of 25-year crusade against taxes; finds that as result of tax-cut crusade there is now fundamental mismatch between benefts Americans expect to receive from government and revenue government collects; finds mismatch already having profound affect at state and local levels: teachers and police are being laid off and children are being denied health insurance; observes that federal government can mask its problems for a while, by running huge budget deficits, but it, too, will eventually have to decide whether to cut services or raise taxes; discusses origins of antitax crusade, and where is it taking us; tax policy under Presidents Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton and George W Bush reviewed; Krugman observes that while it might seem impossible to put populist gloss on tax cuts so skewed toward the rich, Bush administration has been remarkably successul in doing just that; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Community resistance to a walk-in clinic that offers people with psychiatric disorders access to new treatments under the supervision of a renowned expert sadly reflects the pervasive stigma of mental illness. We doubt that a clinic for diabetes or sleep disorders would elicit such a negative response. But the fear of ''mentally disturbed people roaming the residential block'' is archaic. Suggesting that psychiatric patients should be removed from their communities is wrongheaded and bad medicine.

headline.main: No 'Broken Promises' Downtown; A Psychiatric Clinic And Its Patients

docs.abstract: Letter by Sue Matorin and Dr Lisa Sombrotto, who work at New York Presyterian Hospital and are faculty members of Weill Medical College's department of psychiatry, holds neighborhood clinic opened by Dr Ronald Fieve offers people with psychiatric disorders access to new treatments

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton seized the Democratic stage tonight, offering one of his strongest denunciations of President Bush since leaving office as he tried to rally Democrats here around candidates who have yet to stir the excitement he did in 1992. Speaking without notes or a prepared text, Mr. Clinton invoked the circumstances of the 2000 presidential election as he argued that the Bush administration had squandered the domestic and foreign policy gains he had made in his eight years in office.

headline.main: Clinton Aims Barbs at Bush At Gathering For Hopefuls

docs.abstract: Former Pres Clinton charges that Pres Bush has squandered domestic and foreign policy gains he made in eight years in office, speech in Iowa rallying fellow Democrats around presidential aspirants; photo with Tom Harkin (M)
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton seized the Democratic stage tonight, offering one of his strongest denunciations of President Bush since leaving office as he tried to rally Democrats here around candidates who have yet to stir the excitement he did in...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was hard to read Chris Ballard's article (Aug. 31) and not be sick, but I hope it helps bring about the end of eating competitions. Beyond the obvious contempt they show for those who do not have enough food to live, along with the potential health problems that could come from abusing a body this way, they raise questions I'd like to see the Ethicist address. (Should a restaurant have to let someone ''train'' at its buffet table? Should health insurance have to cover the associated costs?) Other sports produce a more fit body and often originated in what were once useful life skills (swimming, skiing, javelin throwing). Overeating is about as much a sport as binge drinking or setting a sexual record. Trudy J. Kuehner Philadelphia

headline.main: 'That Stomach Is Going to Make You Money Someday'

docs.abstract: Trudy J Kuehner letter says it is hard to read Chris Ballard's Aug 31 article on eating competitions and not be sick; expresses hope it helps bring about end of such competitions

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Bush informed the nation last Sunday night that remaining in Iraq next year will cost another $87 billion, many of those who will actually pay that bill were unable to watch. They had already been put to bed by their parents. Administration officials acknowledged the next day that every dollar of that cost will be borrowed, a loan that economists say will be repaid by the next generation of taxpayers and the generation after that. The $166 billion cost of the work so far in Iraq and Afghanistan, which has stunned many in Washington, will be added to what was already the largest budget deficit the nation has ever known.

headline.main: Dizzying Dive to Red Ink Poses Stark Choices for Washington

docs.abstract: Pres Bush's revelation to nation that Iraq next year will cost another $87 billion was probably not heard by future taxpayers who will have to pay bill when they grow up; administration acknowledges that every borrowed dollar, $166 billion so far for Iraq and Afghanistan, will be repaid by next generation and one after that; Iraq costs have pushed to forefront budget deficit that will require painful choices between military spending and electrical grids and between low taxes now and lower retirement payments later; Democrats and most mainstream economists reject administration claim that it can do it all, once economy picks up; bleak choices were hard to imagine when Bush took office 32 months ago, when government was flush with cash from 1990's boom; balanced budgets promised to end wasteful interest payments and years of arguments between military and domestic spenders; economic slump, tax-cutting and effects of Sept 11 terrorist attacks caused surplus to disappear, replaced by huge deficits; former budget official Robert D Reischauer notes 'Miltonian experience,' from heights to depths; current White House budget director Joshua Bolten defends running deficits now; photo; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An important reason that increasingly more older workers are in the work force (front page, Sept. 8) is that after retirement they can be rehired on the cheap with no health or retirement benefits.

headline.main: Older and Working? Why We Have Jobs

docs.abstract: Frank V Effenberger letter says one reason for expanding role of older Americans in work force (Sept 8 article) is that they can be be rehired on the cheap after retirement and do not require health benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There is one important reason more older workers stay in or return to the work force after age 55 (''Older Workers Are Thriving Despite Recent Hard Times,'' front page, Sept. 8). How else can we obtain affordable health insurance -- especially if we have a history of serious or chronic illness?

headline.main: Older and Working? Why We Have Jobs

docs.lead_paragraph: Yup, it's constitutional amendment time again in Texas. Time for another stab at improving, or at any rate expanding, an already enormous document of 82,800 words, more than eight times as long as the federal Constitution, that has been amended no fewer than 410 times since 1876, according to the Texas Legislative Reference Library. And 174 other efforts failed. In other states, legislators pass bills. In Texas, they put it into the Constitution. It happens again on Saturday, when voters will decide on almost two dozen amendments to the bulging document. (Only Alabama's Constitution is longer -- a whopping 315,000 words, with 740 amendments.)

headline.main: Yells Replace Yawns In a Texas Ballot Ritual

docs.abstract: Texas voters, who routinely amend state's constitution with little fuss, are campaigning energetically on both sides of proposed amendment that would bar courts from setting or reviewing noneconomic damages against doctors and medical providers; Legislature has already capped such claims, but Gov Rick Perry says amendment is still needed to curb influence of trial lawyers, lower malpractice premiums and halt drain on doctors out of Texas; opponents see measure as assault on state's Bill of Rights and fear it will open door to efforts by corporations accused in pollution or injury cases to close off defendants' access to courts; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Yup, it's constitutional amendment time again in Texas. Time for another stab at improving, or at any rate expanding, an already enormous document of 82,800 words, more than eight times as long as the federal Constitution, that has been amended no...

docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly 30 years, Jim Greathouse was part of the blue-collar elite, a tool-and-die man who sometimes earned more than $50,000 a year because his job, making the precision metal molds that factories use to shape parts, required such exacting skills. But in June, Mr. Greathouse, 55, lost his job at the Hoover vacuum cleaner factory here, and with so many other factories laying off people, he is at a loss about what to do.

headline.main: As Factory Jobs Disappear, Ohio Town Has Few Options

docs.abstract: Canton, Ohio, long booming industrial center, has been so hard-hit by loss of factory jobs that many workers are losing hope; many of unemployed are reluctantly turning to less steady or lower-paying jobs; laid-off workers comment; photos (M)3

docs.lead_paragraph: It is lunchtime, and the door to Boca Urology's office is locked. But outside, patients are milling about, calling the office on their cellphones, hoping the receptionist will let them in. To say they are eager hardly does them justice. ''We never used to lock the door at lunch, but they came in an hour early,'' said Ellie Fertel, the office manager. ''It's like they're waiting for a concert. Sometimes we forget to lock the door and they come in and sit in the dark.''

headline.main: Patients in Florida Lining Up For All That Medicare Covers

docs.abstract: Article in series Re-Examining Medicare focuses on heavy demand for covered services in Boca Raton, Fla, where doctor visits have become social activity for elderly; South Florida's large population of affluent, educated older people and doctors makes for lavish use of medical services; many patients have 8 or more specialists and visit one or more of them most days, all paid for by Medicare; researchers cite city as case study of what happens when people have unlimited access to medical care; note Medicare coverage and size of reimbursement determine what procedures are performed, making costs hard to control; Medicare spends more per person in South Florida than almost anywhere else, with no apparent medical benefit; graphs of resources, services and outcomes; photo (M)
